nodes.text: A likelihood-based vector autoregressive (VAR) framework can model and provide inference for cointegration among nonstationary economic time series

The cointegrated VAR model formulation is Δx_t = αβ' x_{t-1} + sum_{i=1}^{k-1} Γ_i Δx_{t-i} + deterministic terms + ε_t with rank(αβ') = r describing r cointegration relations and p−r stochastic trends

Granger Representation Theorem: under the I(1) condition the VAR solution has moving average representation with C = β_⊥(α_⊥' Γ β_⊥)^{-1}α_⊥' and xt decomposes into r stationary relations β' x_t and p−r common stochastic trends α_⊥' sum ε_i

Reduced rank regression (RRR) provides ML estimates in the cointegrated VAR by solving an eigenvalue problem on residual cross moments and yields estimators for β, α and Ω and the maximized likelihood |Omega_hat| = |S00| prod_{i=1}^r(1−λ_i)

Likelihood ratio test for cointegration rank r versus p uses −2 log LR = −T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1−λ_i) and its asymptotic distribution depends on number of common trends p−r and deterministic terms (Dickey-Fuller type limits)

Estimator properties: β-hat (properly normalized) has mixed Gaussian limit while α-hat and short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and asymptotically independent of β-hat, enabling χ2 inference for many hypotheses on β

Examples motivate cointegration: purchasing power parity (PPP) implies a stationary linear combination of exchange rate and price levels; present value models imply cointegration between stock price and dividend

Definition and I(1) condition: xt is I(1) if Δx_t is a linear process with C(1) ≠ 0; cointegration exists when nonzero β makes β' x_t stationary; I(1) condition includes |α_⊥' Γ β_⊥| ≠ 0 to avoid I(2) behavior

RRR algorithm: compute residuals correcting for lags and deterministics, form moment matrices S_ij, solve eigenproblem |λ S_ww.z − S_wu.z S_uu.z^{-1} S_uw.z|=0, then β_hat = eigenvectors and α_hat = S_uw.z β_hat

Likelihood maximization under linear restrictions on β (including many economically motivated restrictions) can be implemented by modified RRR or a switching RRR algorithm when constraints are more complex

Asymptotic distribution of rank test with linear trend: limit involves functionals of Brownian motion F(u) = [B(u); u] and depends only on p−r and deterministic trend specification, requiring simulation or tabulated critical values

Interpretation of cointegrating coefficients: they represent long-run equilibrium relations and can be interpreted as the effect of a long-run change in one variable on another when other long-run values are held fixed via the mapping k = C xi and the attractor set {x: β' x = 0}

Asymptotic inference: Wald and likelihood ratio tests on β are asymptotically χ2 under suitable identification and normalization; finite-sample corrections and bootstrap are important because small samples can distort size

Extensions: rational expectations impose testable linear restrictions linking cointegration and short-run dynamics; I(2) models require alternative parametrizations allowing cointegration between levels and differences and yield more complex limit distributions

I(2) modeling result: when α_⊥' Γ β_⊥ has reduced rank the system can be parametrized to identify τ such that τ' Δx_t are I(1) and β' x_t + ψ' Δx_{t-1} are stationary, enabling ML estimation via switching parametrizations but producing new Dickey-Fuller type limits
Limitations and open problems: small sample corrections, nonlinear cointegration theory, and integration of empirical cointegration findings into economic theory remain important unresolved issues
